original_data.question: A 15-year-old female presents to her pediatrician’s office for severe menstrual cramping. The patient underwent menarche at age 11, and her periods were irregular every 2-3 months for two years. After that, her cycles became roughly regular every 28-35 days, but she has had extremely painful cramps and often has to miss school. The cramps are intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen, and there is usually accompanying back pain. The patient has been using heating pads with limited relief. She reports some periods being “really heavy” and requires a superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any bowel or bladder changes. The patient had normal development throughout childhood, is on the soccer team at school, and is not sexually active. Her father has hypertension and her mother has endometriosis and heavy periods. On exam, the patient is 5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2). She is well appearing and has no abdominal tenderness. She has Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair, and external genitalia are normal. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps?

model_response:
The patient’s age, history of irregular periods at the beginning of menarche, and heavy periods with cramps are consistent with a diagnosis of adolescent dysmenorrhea. The patient’s obesity (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2) is also a risk factor for dysmenorrhea. NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for adolescent dysmenorrhea. In this case, the patient’s obesity likely contributes to her symptoms, and weight loss through increased exercise would likely improve her symptoms. Therefore, option C is the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps.

Adolescent dysmenorrhea is defined as menstrual pain accompanied by other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, or dizziness in the absence of any identifiable pelvic pathology. It is common in early adolescence and typically improves over time. Dysmenorrhea is typically described as cramping pain, although it can also be sharp and focal. It is usually limited to the first and second days of menses. Adenomyosis, endometriosis, and leiomyomas can cause dysmenorrhea, but these conditions are rare in adolescents.

The most common cause of dysmenorrhea is anovulation, which is usually associated with menorrhagia. Anovulation can be caused by hormonal imbalances such as polycystic ovarian syndrome, medications (oral contraceptives), or thyroid abnormalities. Obesity is also a risk factor for dysmenorrhea.

The evaluation of a patient with dysmenorrhea should include a thorough history and physical examination. Laboratory studies may be indicated, including a pregnancy test, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and prolactin. An abdominal ultrasound may be indicated if there is a family history of pelvic masses or if the physical examination is abnormal.

The differential diagnosis of menstrual cramping includes premenstrual syndrome (PMS), endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, ovarian cysts, ectopic pregnancy, and adnexal torsion. PMS is characterized by cramping pain, bloating, breast tenderness, and mood changes that occur in the week preceding menses. The diagnosis of endometriosis is based on clinical suspicion, supported by examination findings and confirmed by laparoscopy. The diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease is based on clinical suspicion, supported by examination findings, and confirmed by diagnostic tests such as endometrial biopsy, cultures, or ultrasound. Ovarian cysts and ectopic pregnancy can cause abdominal pain, but the pain is not usually cyclic.

Management of adolescent dysmenorrhea is usually symptomatic. NSAIDs are the first-line treatment. If NSAIDs are ineffective, oral contraceptives can be used. Other treatments that have been used with some success include gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists, low-dose oral contraceptives, and the levonorgestrel intrauterine system.

In this case, the patient’s obesity is likely contributing to her symptoms. Therefore, the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps is increased exercise to promote weight loss.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

A sustained and usually painful contraction of muscle fibers. This may occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a manifestation of an underlying disease process (e.g., UREMIA; HYPOTHYROIDISM; MOTOR NEURON DISEASE; etc.). (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1398)
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The first MENSTRUAL CYCLE marked by the initiation of MENSTRUATION.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Lacking perfect symmetry or evenness.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
An event or sequence of events that constitute a round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Educational institutions.

A sustained and usually painful contraction of muscle fibers. This may occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a manifestation of an underlying disease process (e.g., UREMIA; HYPOTHYROIDISM; MOTOR NEURON DISEASE; etc.). (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1398)
Periodically stopping and starting.
An enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of ACETYLCHOLINE to CHOLINE and acetate. In the CNS, this enzyme plays a role in the function of peripheral neuromuscular junctions. EC 3.1.1.7.
A point or area that is approximately central within some larger region or structure.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Acute or chronic pain located in the posterior regions of the THORAX; LUMBOSACRAL REGION; or the adjacent regions.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Pads designed to provide heat to an area of the human body. These pads are usually made of several layers of soft (e.g., natural fibers, plastics) materials sealed in a fabric or plastic outer covering. The pads may include: (1) heating elements (e.g., wires) connected to an external power source, (2) a heat conducting layer (e.g., carbon polymer) placed on a flexible (e.g., viscoelastic foam) pad that conducts heat supplied by a low voltage power source, or (3) a set of or channels appropriate to circulate warm liquids from an external pump. Heating pads are mainly used to alleviate pain, help in treating muscle spasms and joint stiffness; they are also used to prevent hypothermia. Dedicated heating pads are conformed in a variety of shapes and sizes according to the anatomic part to be heated.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
An event or sequence of events that constitute a round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.
An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions.
The section of the alimentary canal from the STOMACH to the ANAL CANAL. It includes the LARGE INTESTINE and SMALL INTESTINE.
A musculomembranous sac along the URINARY TRACT. URINE flows from the KIDNEYS into the bladder via the ureters (URETER), and is held there until URINATION.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A time period that begins at the beginning of the human embryonic stage and continues until the end of adolescence.
A game in which a round inflated ball is advanced by kicking or propelling with any part of the body except the hands or arms. The object of the game is to place the ball in opposite goals.
Educational institutions.
A response indicating that an individual is or was sexually active.
Male parents, human or animal.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Female parents, human or animal.
A condition in which functional endometrial tissue is present outside the UTERUS. It is often confined to the PELVIS involving the OVARY, the ligaments, cul-de-sac, and the uterovesical peritoneum.
Excessive uterine bleeding during MENSTRUATION.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The distal extremity of the leg in vertebrates, consisting of the tarsus (ANKLE); METATARSUS; phalanges; and the soft tissues surrounding these bones.
A traditional unit of length equal to 1/12 of a foot or 2.54 centimeters.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
The traditional unit of mass. By international agreement, one avoirdupois pound is equal to exactly 0.453 592 37 kilogram, 16 ounces, or 1.215 28 troy pounds.
In humans, one of the paired regions in the anterior portion of the THORAX. The breasts consist of the MAMMARY GLANDS, the SKIN, the MUSCLES, the ADIPOSE TISSUE, and the CONNECTIVE TISSUES.
A bone that forms the lower and anterior part of each side of the hip bone.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.
The external genitalia of the female. It includes the CLITORIS, the labia, the vestibule, and its glands.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

A sustained and usually painful contraction of muscle fibers. This may occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a manifestation of an underlying disease process (e.g., UREMIA; HYPOTHYROIDISM; MOTOR NEURON DISEASE; etc.). (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1398)
